Introduction

Adrenal incidentalomas are adrenal masses discovered inadvertently during imaging studies performed for reasons unrelated to suspected adrenal disease.  The widespread use of high-resolution imaging techniques has led to an increase in the incidental detection of these lesions.  Although most are benign and nonfunctioning, a significant minority (10%-15%) can be malignant or hormone-producing, necessitating careful evaluation and management.  The clinical significance of adrenal incidentalomas lies in distinguishing benign from malignant lesions and determining whether they are hormonally active because these factors influence the management approach.

Pathogenesis



The mechanisms that lead to the development of adrenal incidentalomas are not fully understood.  However, several factors may contribute to their formation:



  • Genetic alterations:  These changes may be sporadic mutations (eg, PRKACA, beta-catenin) or, less commonly, hereditary mutations (eg, MEN1, TP53).
  • Hormonal stimulation:  Chronic adrenal stimulation by factors such as ACTH may promote hyperplasia and eventual tumor formation.
  • Aging:  The increased prevalence of adrenal incidentaloma with age suggests that cumulative cellular damage may play a role.

Epidemiology and classification



Adrenal incidentalomas are found in approximately 4%-5% of abdominal CT scans.  Prevalence increases with age (eg, <1% in patients age <30, 7% in patients age >70).  Adrenal incidentalomas are classified based on their functional status and malignant potential:



  • Benign nonfunctioning adenomas (approximately 75% of cases)
  • Benign functioning adenomas producing the following excess hormones:
    • Cortisol (Cushing syndrome)
    • Aldosterone (primary hyperaldosteronism)
    • Catecholamines (pheochromocytoma)


Rarely, incidentalomas represent adrenocortical carcinoma, metastasis, or other rare tumors (eg, myelolipomas, ganglioneuromas).

Clinical presentation



Most adrenal incidentalomas are asymptomatic at the time of discovery (hence the term "incidentaloma").  However, some may produce clinical signs or symptoms related to hormone excess:



  • Cushing syndrome:  Typically presents as subclinical disease due to mild cortisol excess without overt clinical features (eg, moon face) (
    figure 1
    )
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism:  Presents with hypertension and hypokalemia that may be spontaneous or reveal itself following thiazide initiation for hypertension
  • Pheochromocytoma:  Usually subclinical in presentation but can cause paroxysmal hypertension, palpitations, and sweating


Rarely, large tumors can cause local mass effects, such as abdominal or flank pain.

Diagnosis and evaluation



The evaluation of adrenal incidentalomas involves determining the risk of malignancy and assessing for hormone overproduction.

Risk of malignancy



CT scan is the primary imaging modality for characterizing adrenal masses:



  • Size:  Masses >4 cm are more likely to be malignant.
  • Density:  An unenhanced CT attenuation value of <10 Hounsfield units is diagnostic of adenoma.
  • Appearance:  Irregular shape, heterogeneity, and calcifications suggest malignancy.


Specific radiographic features can sometimes help distinguish between different adrenal masses.

Hormonal evaluation



All patients with adrenal incidentalomas should undergo hormonal evaluation, the extent of which depends on clinical and radiographic findings.



  • Pheochromocytoma:  Pheochromocytoma should be excluded with 24-hour urine testing of catecholamines and fractionated metanephrines, particularly if attenuation is â‰¥10 Hounsfield units on CT imaging.
  • Cushing syndrome:  All patients should be screened for Cushing syndrome (including subclinical forms) with an overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test (after excluding pheochromocytoma to avoid a catecholaminergic crisis) and measurement of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S), a precursor hormone secreted by the adrenal glands.  Low DHEA-S levels strengthen the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome because they reflect chronic ACTH suppression due to hypercortisolism.
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism:  Patients with hypertension or hypokalemia should be screened for primary hyperaldosteronism by measuring plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) and plasma renin activity (PRA) (diagnosis is suggested by PAC >15 ng/dL in conjunction with a PAC/PRA ratio >20-30).


Of note, high levels of DHEA-S indicate increased adrenal androgen secretion, usually seen in adrenocortical carcinomas.  These are highly aggressive malignant tumors with a poor prognosis that can usually be distinguished from adenomas on imaging.  When functional, these carcinomas often present with feminization in men (eg, gynecomastia, testicular atrophy) due to disruption of the estrogen/testosterone ratio (eg, gonadal testosterone suppression); in women, functional adrenocortical carcinomas cause dysfunctional uterine bleeding.

Management



The management of adrenal incidentalomas depends on their imaging characteristics and hormonal activity.

Surgical management



Indications for surgery include:



  • Size >4 cm or other imaging characteristics suspicious for malignancy
  • Hormone-producing tumors (except some cases of mild hypercortisolism)
  • Significant growth on follow-up imaging


The preferred surgical approach is laparoscopic adrenalectomy; large or potentially malignant tumors require open adrenalectomy.

Conservative management



For small (<4 cm), nonfunctioning adenomas with benign imaging characteristics, management involves:



  • Repeat imaging within 6-12 months to ensure stability
  • Annual hormonal evaluation for 4-5 years
  • Considering discontinuation of follow-up if the mass remains stable and nonfunctioning after 4-5 years

Special considerations



  • Pheochromocytomas:  Patients require alpha-blockade before surgery to prevent perioperative complications (due to catecholaminergic crisis from tumor manipulation).
  • Cortisol-producing adenomas:  Patients may require perioperative glucocorticoid replacement (to prevent adrenal crisis from withdrawal) and gradual tapering postoperatively.
  • Aldosterone-producing adenomas:  Surgical cure rates are high, but some patients may require ongoing antihypertensive medication.
  • Adrenocortical carcinomas:  Open adrenalectomy is preferred for complete resection.  Fine-needle aspiration cannot reliably distinguish between adrenal adenomas and carcinoma but may be used to confirm suspected metastasis.

Summary



Adrenal incidentalomas (

figure 2
) are adrenal masses discovered inadvertently during imaging studies performed for unrelated reasons.  These lesions require careful evaluation for malignancy risk and hormonal activity.  The 3 main hyperfunctioning conditions associated with these tumors are Cushing syndrome (cortisol excess), primary hyperaldosteronism (aldosterone excess), and pheochromocytoma (catecholamine excess).  Management decisions are based on tumor size, imaging characteristics, and presence of hormonal activity.  Surgery is indicated for larger tumors (>4 cm), those suspicious for malignancy, or hormone-producing lesions.  Small, benign-appearing, nonfunctioning adenomas can be managed conservatively with periodic follow-up imaging and hormonal evaluation.
